[API] Return 403 for POST requests when user is not authorized

In the policy_enforcement module if policy.enforce() will raise
PolicyNotAuthorized exception, there is additional check if user is
trying to modify own or someone else resource. In case when user is not
allowed to show resource even, error 404 is raised to "hide" any
information about requested resource.
But that was also the case for POST (create resource) requests and 404
error when user is trying e.g. create network is confusing.
So this patch modifies that logic and in case of "create_" actions it
will return 403 if user was not authorized to do such operation.

subject: Disable auto discovery
commit_message:
Disable auto discovery

Tripleo-ci jobs are broken after latest release of setuptools 61.0
because of breaking changes which are not backwork compatible,
details in related bug and [1].

Users that don't set ``packages``, ``py_modules``, or `configuration`
are still likely to observe the auto-discovery behavior, which may
halt the build if the project contains multiple directories and/or
multiple Python files directly under the project root.

To disable auto discovery, one can do below in setup.py

~~~
setuptools.setup(..,packages=[],..)
~~~

or

~~~
setuptools.setup(..,py_modules=[],..)
~~~

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/3197

subject: Update of OVN controllers as an external task.
commit_message:
Update of OVN controllers as an external task.

OVN requires ovn_controller to be updated before ovn_northd.

This implement a new step in the update process to be run before
"overcloud update run ..." commands and after "overcloud update
prepare".

Running:

  openstack overcloud external-update run --stack qe-Cloud-0 --tags ovn

triggers an update of the ovn_controller containers on every
server in parallel.

We don't add the whole configuration of the ovn_controller here,
meaning we *don't* run puppet for the new ovn_controller. Maybe this
should be added as an option, but the time taken by this step will
increase. Current testing show that it's not mandatary to have a
successful update.

Note that new configuration will be taken into account later during
the "update run" commands.

By doing this we avoid any issues where a discrepency in version
between ovn-northd and ovn-controller would cause a cut in the
data-plane.

Change-Id: Icc58fa5f3ccfea9b12154629be977504fe97b45f

subject: Fix failure in dpdk driver binding with VF during reboot
commit_message:
Fix failure in dpdk driver binding with VF during reboot

On a start/reboot, os-net sriov_config.service is run to
create VFs for nic-partitioned devices. If vfio-pci driver
is bound to any of the VFs, the VF initialisation doesn't occur properly.
The VF creation has to be completed before driverctl vfio-pci
binding AND all network interface configs. Since the order of
sriov_config service or driverctl could not be set due to cyclic
dependencies, the driverctl --nosave is used for every reboots
for VFs that needs driver override. This is required in case of
DPDK - NIC Partitioning.

Conflicts:
       os_net_config/common.py
       os_net_config/utils.py
       os_net_config/sriov_config.py
       os_net_config/tests/test_utils.py

Changes are done to exclude refactoring backport done specifically
for vDPA. Also backporting only the required changes with required
factoring.

CI: Don't download Cirros or IPA in seed jobs

We build IPA images in the seed jobs, so we don't need to download IPA
images. We don't use the deployment image, so we don't need to download
Cirros. Also, these downloads depend on external resources which may
make jobs less reliable.

For seed upgrade jobs, disable IPA and deployment image downloads.

This backport also includes the follow up change,
Ibc46a18d00c4c51b67ea18f24a4dd138ef59a4ff:

CI: use dib.yml for bifrost overrides

Follow up to Ib59c8bc2d8938eca18c943bb2e66ed185152a739, which stopped
downloads of the Cirros image in the seed jobs, but inadvertently
enabled DIB builds in the seed upgrade job. This is because
kolla-ansible sets create_image_via_dib to true in dib.yml, and that
file takes precedence over bifrost.yml.

This change fixes the issue by providing Bifrost overrides in CI using
dib.yml.

subject: Pre-empt in-progress nested stack updates on new update
commit_message:
Pre-empt in-progress nested stack updates on new update

If the parent resource of a nested stack is locked due to an IN_PROGRESS
update, cancel the nested stack update (which will result in the parent
resource being marked FAILED and releasing the lock so that the new
traversal can begin acting on it). This also cancels all descendants of
the nested stack.

This means that a concurrent update no longer gets blocked at a nested
stack boundary until the previous update has finished.

subject: Retry port_update in the OVN if revision mismatch during live-migration
commit_message:
Retry port_update in the OVN if revision mismatch during live-migration

This is terrible hack but it seems that there is no other way to
fix/workaround the race which may happen during live-migration between:
- port update event comming from the OVN db (port DOWN on the src node),
- API call from nova-compute to activate port binding on the destination
node.

If those 2 events will be executed in specific order by different
workers it may happen that port binding activation will not update
"requested_chassis" of the port in OVN northd due to revision mismatch
(ovn_revision and neutron_revision will be already bumped by the worker
which processes "port update" OVN event).
If "requested_chassis" will not be updated, OVN will not claim port on
the dest node thus connectivity to the vm will be broken.

To workaround that issue, port_update_postcommit method from the OVN
mechanism driver will catch RevisionMismatch exception raised by the
ovn_client and in case that this was port_update after live_migration,
will get port data from neutron db and try to update port in the OVN
northd once again.

Closes-bug: #1967144
Change-Id: If6e1c6e0fc772101bcd3427601800aaae84381dd

With ephemeral heat we lost the meaning of the 'stack_action' hiera key
which we previously used to distinguish between fresh deployment and
pre-existing deployment (aka redeploy).
Since this hiera key is not available anymore, in ansible we added a
TRIPLEO_HA_WRAPPER_RESOURCE_EXISTS env variable which will be true
when the resource existed even before calling puppet.

This way we can restore the previous behaviour (which was relying
on the stack_update hiera key) of restarting an HA
bundle on the bootstrap node in case of a configuration change.

While we're at it we make sure that the logging takes place via logger

subject: compute: Allow deleting of other users' keypairs
commit_message:
compute: Allow deleting of other users' keypairs

Admins are allowed to delete keypairs belonging to another user by
passing the 'user_id' query string parameter, for example:

  DELETE /keypairs/{keypair}?user_id=foo

Unfortunately while we were passing through a 'user_id' argument to the
underlying 'openstack.proxy.Proxy._delete' call, this was being used to
populate the 'user_id' body parameter of the 'Keypair' resource as
opposed to the query string parameter. We can't easily change this
because a number of calls to this function involve nested resources, for
example 'openstack.image.v2._proxy.Proxy.remove_member', which must
actually pass the arguments through to the 'Resource'.

Resolve this by adding a 'param' argument to the underlying
'openstack.proxy.Proxy._delete' API, which can be used to pass through
the additional query string parameters to the delete call.

subject: amqp1: fix race when reconnecting
commit_message:
amqp1: fix race when reconnecting

Currently this is how reconnect works:

- pyngus detects failure and invokes callback
  Controller.connection_failed() which in turn calls
  Controller._handle_connection_loss()

- The first thing that _handle_connection_loss does is to set
  self.addresser to None (important later)

- Then it defers _do_reconnect after a delay (normally 1 second)

- (1 second passes)

- _do_reconnect calls _hard_reset which resets the controller state

However, there is a race here.  This can happen:

- The above, up until it defers and waits for 1 second

- Controller.send() is invoked on a task

- A new Sender is created, and critically because self.reply_link
  still exists and is active, we call sender.attach and pass in
  self.addresser.  Remember _handle_connection_loss sets
  self.addresser to None.

- Eventually Sender.attach throws an AttributeError because it
  attempts to call addresser.resolve() but addresser is None

The reason this happens is because although the connection is dead,
the controller state is still half-alive because _hard_reset hasn't
been called yet since it's deferred one second in _do_reconnect.

The fix here is to move _hard_reset out of _do_reconnect and directly
into _handle_connection_loss.  The eventloop is woken up immediately
to process _hard_reset but _do_reconnect is still deferred as before
so as to retain the desired reconnect backoff behavior.

Closes-Bug: #1941652

(cherry picked from commit 02a38f507d8f0c377a2ef468e3497b5e897f1b09)

subject: Expose block-device-allocate-retries and interval
commit_message:
Expose block-device-allocate-retries and interval

The upstream has 3 min as the timeout (60 retries at 3-seconds
interval). It should work if an image is in a raw format to leverage
Ceph's copy-on-write or an image is small enough to be copied quickly.
However, there are some cases exeeding the 3 min deadline such as a big
enough image with Qcow2 or other formats like Windows images, or storage
backend doesn't have copy-on-write from Glance.

Let's bump the deadline to 15 min (300 retries at 3-seconds interval) to
cover most of the cases out of the box, and let operators tune it
further by exposing those options.

subject: More robust fix to trunk deletion race condition
commit_message:
More robust fix to trunk deletion race condition

When a VM is rebooted and it has a port in a trunk with DPDK and
vhostuserclient mode, Nova will delete the OVS port and then recreate it
when the VM reboots. This quick transition can create a race condition
between the trunk addition and deletion, causing the former to fail
because the latter deletes the trunk bridge. In this change we add
a dictionary to track trunks pending to be created, so the trunk
deletion can back off and not delete the bridge when a creation for the
same trunk arrives concurrently. This change also removes the wait
introduced by [1] and [2].

This change is associated to [3] on the os-vif side.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/714783
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/827580
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-vif/+/830103

subject: Ensure that re_added ports are DOWN before set back to UP
commit_message:
Ensure that re_added ports are DOWN before set back to UP

During e.g. rebuild of the server by Nova, ports plugged to such server
are quickly removed and added again into br-int. In such case, ports are
in the "re_added" ports set in the neutron-ovs-agent.
But it seems that in some cases it may happen that such port isn't
switched to be DOWN first and then, when neutron-ovs-agent treats port
as added/updated and reports to the server that port is UP, there is no
notification to nova-compute send (because port's status was UP and new
status is still UP in the Neutron DB).
As Nova waits for the notification from Neutron in such case server
could ends up in the ERROR state.

To avoid such issue, all ports which are treated as "re_added" by the
neutron-ovs-agent are now first switched to be DOWN on the server side.
That way, when those ports are treated as added/updated in the same
rpc_loop iteration, switching their status to UP will for sure trigger
notification to nova.

Closes-Bug: #1963899
Change-Id: I0df376a80140ead7ff1fbf7f5ffef08a999dbe0b
(cherry picked from commit e7edcec2608fe1cb30d7458a882eb81e058eb76e)

subject: db: shard up the DatabaseBroker pending files
commit_message:
db: shard up the DatabaseBroker pending files

When we get concurrent workers attempting to update the same container
or account DB there can be contention on locks, and with enough
connections can lead to timeouts. This happens for 2 reasons, there is
only 1 pending file and secondly we do a directory level lock when we
want to update it.
When the pending file gets big enough, also causing further locking and
potential contention as that single pending file needs to be locked and
commited into the database.

A pending file is a write ahead log. It allows us to quickly take, say a
container obj put, and write it without having to commit it to the
container database straight away.

Under concurrent load, a single pending file is just that a single file
and write locks to the file can cause current processes to queue up.

This patch reworks the locking and pending file semantics:

 1. Allow a configurable amount of pending files (shards) that processes
    can write to.
 2. Create a cycle/ring like structure of pending files so a process
    will attempt to write to a free pending file before it just has to
    wait.
 3. Lock the pending file with a write lock when we're writing to that
    particular file.
 4. Move the directory level lock to only occur when we need to commit
    the pending files into the DB.
 5. When more then one process sees that the pending files need to be
    commited. The first locks the container, any others will fall back
    to appending to a pending file.
 6. When commiting the pending files to the DB, only lock one at a time
    so futher incoming connections can still be appending to other
    pending files.
 7. When looking for pending files to commit, look and see what's in the
    directory and attempt to commit all it finds. The number of pending
    files is configurable. If reduced we don't want to loose any staged
    writes.

A new configuration option `pending_shards` is available and is the number
of pending files to use. The file names are *.pending *-2.pending, etc.

When testing this on my VSAIO, I had a script that would make 200 concurrent
container-server connections and write 20,000 objects. When I upped the
workers to 2, unsing the original code, I'd see alot of serverside timeouts.
With this code and setting the pending_shards to 5 or so (and increasing the
client timeout a little), I managed to get to
5 or 6 workers without getting a single server side timeout.

I did get some client side timeout especially above 6, but that's because
I'm saturating my poor virtual vagant SAIO.

Change-Id: Ib60e71340a4e3884a9a9d70891fe17a0490baa6b

commit_message:
Initial commit for application policy

Commit includes:
* New package type Aspect which will have extended MuranoPL
  reflection capabilities. At this stage methods inside this type
  of packages have the ability to modify properties of any object
* New classes io.murano.policy.Aspect and io.murano.policy.Notifier
* Every aspect instance can subscribe to notifications of
  different events. For now it is only object initialization event.
  To subscribe, it passes itself, name of handler method and name
  of method to check some condition against the processed object
  to notifier's subscribe() method
* Example policy package that inforces usage of some maximum
  instance flavor with test-runner based tests

So now it is possible:
* to write custom aspect code in the form of library package
* to define the aspect rules in json-format and place it to the file
  murano/common/aspects.py (until db tables and api are implemented)
* aspects are notified of the objects initializing event
* aspects can modify the values of object's properties

subject: Extended MuranoPL reflection and package load event
commit_message:
Extended MuranoPL reflection and package load event

1. Methods inside Aspect packages provided with extended
   reflection capabilities:
     * changing type property default value
     * changing type property contract
     * changing method argument default value
     * changing method argument contract
2. Aspects are able to subscribe to package load event
3. DefaultSetter and ContractSetter example policies are added

subject: Ability to add metadata with aspect through extended reflection
commit_message:
Ability to add metadata with aspect through extended reflection

Now aspects are able to use method addMeta(metaclass, props)
to add new metadata to classes, properties, methods and arguments.
